ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The course covered a variety of topics related to graph learning, including basics of graph neural network (GNN), graph attention network (GAT), scalable GNN, expressive power of GNN, some variants of GNNs to tackle specific problems like position-aware GNN and identity-aware GNN, graph generative models, hyperbolic GNN, knowledge graph, etc.
I learned about graph neural networks and the many different flavors therein. We learned about the underlying math as well as many applications of these graph neural networks.
I learnt a great deal about different types of GNN architectures and ongoing research in the field.

This class is about a rapidly growing field that is just 5 years old - Deep Learning on Graphs. Although reasonably niche right now, given that most problems can be formulated in terms of graphs, and given the power of deep learning, I'm sure the material I learned in this class will come into use in the future. The algorithms we discussed in class were elegant yet powerful - and this made the course all the more enjoyable for me.

We covered basics of deep learning, various architectures to build Graph Neural Nets (GNNs), different objectives for Graph learning (supervised, unsupervised, semi-supervised, node classification, edge prediction, graph prediction). Then some advanced topics such as hyperbolic embeddings, biological applications, trustworthy AI, knowledge graphs.
I learned an extensive amount about graph deep learning and the state of the art methods used for it.
GNNs, linear algebra, deep learning
Essentials of GNN
Graph Neural Networks, Graph Convolutional Networks, other graph networks
GNN basics, various architectures for different tasks, read several recent research papers
Application of deep learning on graph structure data.
knowledge about building graph neural network
A good overview about the graph-relates machine learning skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It's a great survey course in graph learning, but it would be very helpful if some of the contents could be explained in greater details rather than just touching upon.

I think a strength of the course were the lectures and the lecture slides. I felt these were very well put together and were quite easy to follow and understand. I thought Rex did a great job putting those together, since they made it easier to follow along during lecture. Additionally, I thought that Rex did a great job of explaining topics during lecture and would always consider students questions carefully.

Some things I didn't like about the course: I thought the homework assignments were a bit disconnected from the lecture materials at times. They often required more personal online research to answer, which was slightly annoying. Additionally, I wish the colab coding assignments were actually more involved so we learned how to code GNNs just as much as the theory. I think the class was a bit theory-heavy despite the emphasis with the final project being so code-heavy. Speaking of the final project, I think it is a bit too much work especially with a final exam. I think because the final project is so involved and so much is expected from the students, it should be kept while the final exam shouldn't be included in future versions of the course. It seems unnecessary for the course to have a final exam, when an emphasis of the class is the final exam. 

Finally, I think Piazza should be used more. It was difficult for me to go to office hours because I am a PhD student with a family. Especially in the later part of the course, Piazza became completely useless for asking questions. Questions would sit for days and go unanswered. There are still many instructor-unanswered questions on piazza today. There aren't many questions posted to Piazza, and a class with 1 instructor and 4 TAs should be able to keep up. If the class chooses to have a piazza site, it should be used in a timely manner. 

Additionally, I think that the solutions to the homeworks should be released so students can more easily learn from their mistakes on the homeworks. Not releasing the homework solutions after they were due was a weakness of the class.

The course covers so much relevant material, and the workload is pretty manageable in terms of homework.
The course does get really heavy however towards the end to come up with a good project and do well on the final requires a good amount of time!!

There was way too much breadth and not enough depth in the course. I'd have preferred if we looked at just a few topics but focused more on application, developing strong foundations. For instance learning everything  from something as simple as converting a dataset into a heterogenous graph all the way up to writing key functions for some of the architectures we covered.

Strengths: 1. There is no one better who can teach you this material. Rex is one of the pioneers in this field, and indeed, many of the lectures dealt with algorithms that he himself was a published author on. 2. Because Rex is a quick lecturer who expects a good amount from his students, lectures cover a vast quantity of super cool material. 3. Although the material taught in lecture is enormous, as far as assessments are concerned, psets and coding projects take only a few hours, and are spaced well throughout the semester. Even the final exam only required basic understanding of the concepts presented, without requiring any of the intricate details. Weaknesses: 1. Given the gigabrain inside Rex's head, it's not a surprise that he moves quickly over concepts, which can sometimes make lectures hard to follow. However, the lecture slides are well-designed, a great reference to review content from lectures. 2. If anything, this course could have had ~more~ assessments, if only to reinforce key concepts more before the final exam.
The course is one of the best I've taken
Strengths: great breadth of content and thus a good introduction to deep learning on graphs; weaknesses: a bit too fast-paced, sometimes lectures contained too much information

Strength: Comprehensive overview
Weakness: maybe should emphasize less of the hyperbolic embedding part
Low workload but emphasized building a strong foundational knowledge. Lenient grading
Good organization of the syllabus, and material

Good: really good slides, passionate lectures, a lot of material
Improvements: the coding homeworks were way too simple and I did not learn a lot there

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Recommend to students who has background on deep learning and want to get to know about graph learning.

I would recommend this course to other students provided the homeworks change to focus more on coding and the final exam is removed. The final exam seemed like busy-work towards the end that got in the way of working on the final project. Still, despite this, I thought the class was well put together and a great review of the cutting edge of graph neural networks. I certainly learned a lot through the class.
Definitely, Rex is such a good teacher and it covers so many relevant topics with enough detail to be practical and implementable
Yes! It's a good survey course for Graph neural network. It covers both theories and applications, and the workload is pretty reasonable.
Not in its current form but I believe there is a lot of potential for this to be a great class.

If you're interested in exciting new avenues of machine learning, and want an elective taught by someone with a brain double your size, take this course. The concepts you learn might come in handy down the line, and even if they don't, the topics are just cool.

This class is the definition of you will get you put into the class. The content covered in this class is super cool but its very advanced (includes lots of random math, very recent research, and blitzes through lots of complex Deep Learning architectures). However, the PSETS (which are 50% of grade) are really easy in comparison (4 mathy ones and 3 coding ones which each take a few hours or less) and are graded very leniently. There is one test (the in-class final) which is also tame and graded leniently. The final project (in groups of 2-3) is to implement or analyze a Graph learning paper which can feel like a significant jump from the PSETs since now you have to actually implement and understand everything while in PSETs you only have to write function snippets. I did 80%+ of my learning from this class on the final project. I have taken an AI class before but this was my first Machine/Deep Learning class. I felt like it was accessible but conceptually hard to grasp which I feel like could have been remedied if I had taken another machine/deep learning class beforehand such as Deep Learning (CS 452) or Intro/Intermediate ML (S&DS 265/365) beforehand. I am proud that I was able to delve into cutting edge research but I feel like my understanding at the end of the day is surface level compared to what some students who specialize in ML may have gotten out. We covered basics of deep learning, various architectures to build Graph Neural Nets (GNNs), different objectives for Graph learning (supervised, unsupervised, semi-supervised, node classification, edge prediction, graph prediction). Then some advanced topics such as hyperbolic embeddings, biological applications, trustworthy AI, knowledge graphs.
Rex is a phenomenal professor and really cares about everyone in the class! One of the smartest professors at Yale!
Yes, I learned a great deal from this course
Yes, best option to learn about GNN
Absolutely recommend for any AI interested students!
Yes, Rex is a good lecturer and cares about the students. Material is interesting and workload is not high.
Yeah. Prof. Ying is responsible and the course slide is easy-understand.
Not really. The content are useful, but the course is not very well organized.
Yes! Really good professor with a high potential
